data.name: Frozen Sick
entries: Något dödar människor i Palebank Village, och om karaktärerna inte stoppar det kan de stå på tur. "Frozen Sick" är ett äventyr som tar karaktärer från 1:a till 3:e nivån och introducerar dem till kontinentens Biting North-region - de dystra arktiska rikena Greying Wildlands och Eiselcross.

Om dina spelare använder sig av hjältekroniken för att skapa sina karaktärer (se {@book chapter 4|EGW|5|Heroic Chronicle}), kan du tillsammans med dem bestämma hur de tog sig till Palebank Village. Är de medborgare i Uthodurn som nu hjälper till med expansionen av deras civilisation på ytan? Har de kommit norrut för att söka frihet från krigen i andra länder? Alla möjliga alternativ kan hjälpa till att knyta karaktärerna till denna kyliga region och de mysterier som den rymmer.

entries.name: Story Overview
entries: Urgon Wenth, en dvärgforskare, återvände nyligen hem till Palebank Village efter att ha utforskat Eiselcross isiga ödemarker i ett år. Dvärgen tog med sig flera föremål hem som plundrats från ruiner på Foren, den största av Eiselcross öar. Bland dessa skatter fanns två vackra blå glasflaskor, som Urgon sålde till en alvsamlare vid namn Verla Pelc. Flaskorna stals sedan, gavs till en hälare utanför Shadycreek Run och såldes återigen till en intet ont anande köpman.

I själva verket är den vackra blå färgen på flaskorna ett resultat av dödliga blå sporer som fastnar på glasets insida. Svaga sprickor i båda flaskorna har utsatt varje person som hanterat dem för frigid woe, en dödlig sjukdom som inte kan botas med konventionella medel. Sjukdomen har redan dödat Urgon och Verla och förvandlat dem till isstatyer. Detaljer om frigid woe finns i avsnittet "{@book Eiselcross|EGW|4}" i kapitel 3.

entries.name: Adventure Summary
entries: När karaktärerna befinner sig i Palebank Village ber samhällsledaren Elro Aldataur dem om hjälp med att ta reda på vem eller vad som har dödat Urgon Wenth. Urgon, en upptäcktsresande som nyligen återvänt från Eiselcross, drabbades av en märklig sjukdom som förvandlade honom till en isstaty, och som sedan dess har visat sig hos en annan av byns invånare. Karaktärerna undersöker mysteriet samtidigt som de kämpar mot Uttolots krafter, en av de kriminella familjer som kontrollerar Shadycreek Run. Fler smittade invånare upptäcks, inklusive en som redan är död, innan karaktärerna rensar ut Uttolots skurkar från ett lokalt grottkomplex som kallas Croaker Cave. I slutändan återvinns flaskorna med frigid woe, men köpmannen Irven Liel och hans familj är smittade och kommer att bli de nästa som dör utan ett botemedel. Karaktärerna kan dessutom mycket väl vara smittade av sjukdomen själva.

Elro ber karaktärerna att resa till Eiselcross för att söka ett botemedel mot frigid woe. Karaktärerna tar en båt till Syrinlya, den uthoduriska utposten på Foren, och följer Urgon Wenths väg till ruinen Salsvault. Detta magiska laboratorium var en gång en del av Aeor, en gammal flygande stadsstat som kraschade in i Eiselcross under kalamiteten. Endast genom att trotsa Salsvaults försvar och dödliga väktare kan äventyrarna hitta motgiftet de behöver.

entries.name: Setup and Starting Points
entries: Arbeta tillsammans med spelarna för att fastställa varför deras karaktärer befinner sig i Palebank Village. Du kan ge information om byn och dess omgivningar, som alla beskrivs i {@book chapter 3|EGW|4|Palebank Village}.
Innan äventyret börjar är det också dags att ta reda på om karaktärerna redan känner varandra eller om det här äventyret är första gången de träffas.

entries.name: Mystery in Palebank Village
entries: Äventyret börjar i Palebank Village och karaktärerna dras omedelbart in i dödsdramat i en isolerad bygd. När spelarna är redo att börja läser du upp eller parafraserar följande för att ställa in scenen:

Snön faller mjukt från himlen och vinden biter dig i kinderna när du står på kyrkogården i Palebank Village, en fiskeutpost i Uthodurn där flera hundra dvärgar och alver bor. Solen står lågt på himlen och sjunker bakom Urgon Wenths färska grav, en gammal dvärg som drabbades av en förbannelse eller sjukdom som förvandlade honom till en isstaty. Folket i byn har samlats för att visa sin sista respekt för Urgons frusna kvarlevor.

Som en del av sina karaktärers bakgrundshistoria kan spelarna bestämma om någon av dem kände Urgon eller om de har kommit till begravningen bara för att visa respekt för folket i samhället. Hur som helst, fortsätt med att läsa följande:

En grov röst talar mjukt bakom dig. "Tack för att du deltar i Urgons gudstjänst." Du vänder dig om och möter blicken av Elro Aldataur, en väderbiten alv, pensionerad ranger och ledare för byn. "Jag är ledsen att tala om mörka nyheter under sådana omständigheter, men jag tror att Palebank Village kan vara i fara, och jag hoppas att du kan hjälpa oss."

Oavsett om karaktärerna är kända i byn som nybörjaräventyrare eller om de bara ser ut som de gör, hoppas Elro (en neutral god, manlig träälv {@creature veteran}) att de är den sortens människor som inte är rädda för att hjälpa folk i nöd. Använd följande punkter för att vägleda samtalet när han förklarar sin oro för karaktärerna:

items: För två månader sedan återvände Urgon Wenth hem efter att ha utforskat Eiselcross i ett år. Han hade bara varit tillbaka i några dagar när han drabbades av en märklig sjukdom som gjorde att dvärgen rörde sig långsamt och fick blåa ådror att dyka upp över hela kroppen.

Byns präster Moradin och Corellon använde alla trollformler de kunde uppbringa för att försöka bota Urgon, men inget av det de försökte kunde stoppa den bisarra sjukdomen. Urgon kämpade mot sjukdomen i veckor, tills hans ständigt långsamma kropp till slut förvandlades till is.

Fram till igår trodde Elro och resten av samhället att Urgons sorgliga öde var en isolerad händelse, troligen orsakad av något som dvärgen kom i kontakt med när han utforskade Eiselcross. Sedan märkte Elro att Tulgi Lutan, en dvärgfångare, visade tecken på samma sjukdom.
Elro försökte tala med Tulgi om det, men hon knuffade bort honom och bad att han skulle låta henne dö i fred.

entries.name: Elro's Request
entries: Om karaktärerna är vill Elro att de ska ta reda på vad som orsakade Urgon och Tulgis sjukdom. Han är orolig för att den kan sprida sig, men Tulgi vägrar att prata med honom, och Glasbladsborna i byn är mer kända för sina stridsfärdigheter än för sin förmåga att få fram sanningen i en komplicerad situation. Dessutom är Tulgi extremt misstänksam mot myndigheterna.

Elro tror att en grupp äventyrare skulle ha större chans att övertyga Tulgi att prata. Om karaktärerna går med på att hjälpa till att hitta orsaken till Urgons och Tullingis åkomma erbjuder Elro att betala dem 100 gp. Han föreslår att karaktärerna börjar med att söka igenom Urgons hem eller prata med Tulgi i hennes stuga.

entries.name: Urgon's Cabin
entries: Urgon Wenth bodde i en timmerstuga med en våning och ett rum i utkanten av staden. En godmodig Glassblade-rookie vid namn Mila Teno (en lagligt god, kvinnlig träälv {@creature scout}) står vakt utanför ytterdörren. Om karaktärerna förklarar varför de har kommit tillåter hon dem att gå in i huset och se sig omkring. När karaktärerna går in i stugan ska du läsa:

Denna trånga, mörka stuga kan ha varit en mysig plats när ägaren levde. Nu står en obäddad säng bredvid en kall eldstad, vars mantel är hängd med huvudet av ett knorrande vitt djur med gråa horn. På andra sidan av rummet står ett litet bord som är översållat med smutsig disk och försett med en dvärgstor stol framför två tomma hyllor vars innehåll är utspridda på golvet: köksredskap, torkade livsmedel, äventyrsutrustning och några böcker.

Alla karaktärer som undersöker röran i stugan inser att någon nyligen förstörde platsen när de letade efter den. En lyckad DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation})-kontroll avslöjar inkräktarens fotspår. Tulgi Lutan var den skyldige, desperat efter alla ledtrådar som kan hjälpa henne att bota den frigida ve som håller på att döda henne. Hennes spår leder utanför och tillbaka till hennes stuga (se "{@adventure Tulgi's Cabin|FS|0|Tulgi's Cabin}" nedan).

entries.name: Adventuring Equipment
entries: Urgons äventyrsutrustning består av en försilvrad maul, en rustning av skenor i storlek för en dvärg, skrymmande, pälsfodrade kläder i storlek för en dvärg, en gripkrok och en lykta med huva.

entries.name: Mounted Head
entries: En karaktär som lyckas med en DC 15 intelligenskontroll ({@skill Nature}) känner igen att huvudet som är monterat ovanför manteln tillhörde en yeti, en monstrositet som hittats i Eiselcross.

entries.name: Strange Receipt
entries: En karaktär som letar bland böckerna på hyllan och lyckas med en DC 10 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation})-kontroll hittar ett vikt kvitto som används som bokmärke. Kvittot är daterat två månader tidigare och anger att Urgon sålde flera aeoriska föremål som hittats i Eiselcross till det lokala antikvariatet Pelc's Curiosities för 1 000 gp. Föremålen anges som en dolk, ett rullfodral, en jadestatuett, ett koger med tjugo pilar, en silverring med en jaspis och två flaskor av blått glas.
Karaktärer som är bosatta i Palebank Village eller har varit där ett tag känner till Pelcs kuriosa - och vet också att butiken rånades och vandaliserades för två månader sedan.

entries.name: Development
entries: Efter att ha genomsökt stugan kan karaktärerna fortsätta sin undersökning genom att gå till Tulgis stuga eller genom att stanna vid Pelcs kuriosa (om de har hittat kvittot).

entries.name: Tulgi's Cabin
entries: När karaktärerna närmar sig Tulgis stuga, läs:
Den snötäckta stugan ser fridfull och tyst ut från utsidan. Fönstren är stängda, och en stadig rökström från skorstenen tyder på att det brinner en brasa där inne.
Tulgi Lutans hem är en timmerstuga med en våning och ett rum. Eftersom hon inte gärna släpper in karaktärerna kan följande egenskaper vara viktiga:

items: Taket på stugan är 12 fot högt. För att klättra uppför ytterväggarna krävs en lyckad DC 10 styrkekontroll ({@skill Athletics}).

Tråddörren till stugan är låst och har AC 15, 18 träffpunkter och är immun mot gift och psykisk skada. Låset kan plockas upp med en lyckad DC 12 Dexterity-kontroll med hjälp av tjuvverktyg, eller så kan dörren tvingas upp med en lyckad DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics})-kontroll. Tulgi bär på nyckeln som låser upp dörren.
Var och en av stugans fyra väggar har ett fönster, som är stängt och låst från insidan. Ett fönster kan låsas upp från utsidan med en lyckad DC 12 Dexterity-kontroll med hjälp av tjuvverktyg.
Stugans insida är starkt upplyst av eldar i en brasa och en öppen spis, även om det rökiga diset från båda gör att interiören är lätt skymd.

entries: Om karaktärerna knackar på dörren ropar Tulgi Lutan (en neutralt ond, kvinnlig bergsdvärg {@creature thug} med en gånghastighet på 10 fot) från andra sidan och ber dem att gå därifrån. En karaktär som ropar tillbaka genom dörren och lyckas med en DC 12-kontroll av Charisma ({@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation} eller {@skill Persuasion}) övertygar Tulgi att öppna dörren och släppa in gruppen. Annars ignorerar hon allt som karaktärerna säger.
Om karaktärerna inte bjuds in måste de bestämma vilka andra medel de är villiga att använda för att komma in. Oavsett hur de gör det, när karaktärerna kommer in i stugan, läs:

Värmen i denna lilla stuga är som ett hammarslag. Ett bord med prydligt staplade tallrikar, verktyg och redskap står i mitten av rummet. Doften av en sjudande soppa kommer från en gryta som hänger i en brusande öppen spis. En annan eld brinner i en järnbrasa i motsatt ände av rummet och fyller stugan med en rökig dimma. I slutet av en säng nära brasan ligger en dvärg inpackad i filtar och ryser. Utbuktande blå ådror strör hennes ansikte, hals och händer.

Om karaktärerna bröt sig in i stugan attackerar Tulgi dem så fort hon ser dem och kämpar tills de har minskat till 10 träffpunkter och sedan ger upp. Hon har två husdjur {@creature Wolf||wolves}, Iro och Jira, som gömmer sig under hennes säng. Om ett slagsmål bryter ut går vargarna in i striden för att försvara henne.

entries.name: Fire Hazards
entries: Alla varelser som kommer i kontakt med brasan eller eldstaden för första gången under sin tur, eller som börjar sin tur där, tar 2 ({@dice 1d4}) brandskador.

entries.name: What Tulgi Knows
entries: Tulgi är hård och rakt på sak och försöker kompensera sin sjukdom med bluff. Om karaktärerna kom in i stugan med hennes tillåtelse eller om hon överlämnar sig till dem, berättar hon bara att hon har samma sjukdom som dödade Urgon och att hon letar efter ett botemedel.
En karaktär som lyckas med en DC 12 Charisma-kontroll ({@skill Intimidation} eller {@skill Persuasion}) övertygar Tulgi att avslöja följande information:

items: Tulgi kom till Palebank Village för några år sedan från Shadycreek Run tillsammans med sin syster {@creature Hulil Lutan|EGW|Hulil}. Båda arbetar för familjen Uttolot.

Uttolots skickade systrarna och några andra till byn för att hålla ett öga på de skatter som kom tillbaka från Eiselcross - med avsikt att stjäla dem. När sådana artefakter kommer genom den lilla bosättningen är det ofta ovanliga varor som skattjägare försöker hålla borta från Uthodurn eller Dwendalian Empire.
När Urgon Wenth återvände till Palebank Village med skatter från Eiselcross såg Tulgi sin chans. Hon väntade på att Urgon skulle sälja sina fynd till Pelc's Curiosities och stal sedan allt.

Tulgi gav de flesta av Urgons reliker till Hulil, men behöll en för sig själv - en utsmyckad dolk. Hon ger motvilligt detta vapen till karaktärerna om hon blir tillfrågad (se "Skatt" nedan). Hulil har de andra föremålen på en plats norr om byn som kallas Croaker Cave.
Tulgi var den som genomsökte Urgons stuga, övertygad om att den döde dvärgen måste ha haft magi eller andra hemligheter förvarade där.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Om Tulgi inte erbjuder karaktärerna sin dolk, lägger alla karaktärer med en passiv visdom ({@skill Perception}) på 11 eller högre märke till det utsmyckade bladet i en förgylld skida som ligger under hennes skjorta. Om karaktärerna kräver {@item +1 dagger}, avslöjar en lyckad DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana} eller {@skill History})-kontroll att dolken är en kvarleva från den fallna flygande staden Aeor.

entries.name: Development
entries: Karaktärerna har inga problem att hitta Croaker Cave eller Pelc's Curiosities om någon av dessa platser är deras nästa destination. Om det gick dåligt med Tulgi och hon dog innan hon avslöjade någon information kan karaktärerna hitta anteckningar eller instruktioner från Hulil som avslöjar en del av informationen ovan.

entries.name: Pelc's Curiosities
entries: Pelc's Curiosities är en antikvitetsaffär som drivs av en introvert alv vid namn Verla Pelc. Verla håller sig för sig själv och öppnar butiken bara när hon känner sig sugen. Hon handlar med alla föremål som intresserar henne och skickar dem över hela Wildemount. Karaktärer som är bosatta i Palebank Village eller har varit där ett tag känner till Pelcs kuriosa - och vet också att butiken rånades och vandaliserades för två månader sedan. Om karaktärerna är nyanlända till byn nämner alla de frågar om butiken rånet.

Pelc's Curiosities är en timmerstuga med en våning och två rum. Fönstren är stängda och låsta inifrån, vilket gör att det är mörkt på insidan. Den enda ingången är ytterdörren, men karaktärer kan tvinga upp en av fönsterluckorna på baksidan med en lyckad DC 12 styrka ({@skill Athletics}) kontroll, vilket ger tillgång till Verlas rum (se det avsnittet nedan).
När karaktärerna närmar sig stugan ska du läsa:

Den mörka stugan framför dig har en skylt över dörren där det står "Pelc's Curiosities", med en bild av en böjd drake som används för att göra bokstaven P. Även om butiken verkar stängd är ytterdörren lätt öppnad.

Alla karaktärer med en passiv Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) poäng på 11 eller högre hör viskande röster och fotsteg inifrån stugan. Om karaktärerna lyckas med en grupp DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth})-kontroll kan de överraska banditerna som för närvarande befinner sig i butiken.

entries.name: Front Shop Area
entries: Antikvariatet ligger i stugans stora främre rum. När karaktärerna kan se in i detta område, läs:
Fem maskerade alver verkar ha plundrat butiken och letar bland de trasiga bråten på golvet. Möblerna, hyllorna och disken har slagits sönder och butikens varor ligger nu på golvet.

Det här området är {@quickref difficult terrain||3} tack vare det skräp som täcker det. De fem alverna är {@creature Bandit||bandits} med {@sense darkvision} på en räckvidd av 60 fot, fördel på räddningskast mot att vara {@condition charmed}, och immunitet mot magi som skulle få dem att sova.

Banditerna attackerar så fort de ser karaktärerna och slåss tills bara en av dem är kvar. Den överlevande kapitulerar sedan. Om en fångad bandit förhörs kan en karaktär som lyckas med en DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation})-kontroll få reda på följande information:

items: Banditerna arbetar för {@creature Hulil Lutan|EGW}, en dvärgprästinna av Tiamat. Hulil arbetar för familjen Uttolot i Shadycreek Run.
Hulils syster Tulgi rånade Pelc's Curiosities för två månader sedan.
Hulil är sjuk eller förbannad med någon sjukdom som gör att hon rör sig långsamt och att hennes ådror blir blå.

Hulil beordrade banditerna att förstöra Pelcs kuriosa i jakt på drycker, skriftrullar eller andra föremål som kunde hjälpa henne att bli botad. Trots sin grundliga genomsökning hittade banditerna ingenting användbart. Hulil gömmer sig med fler banditer i Croaker Cave.

entries.name: Verla's Quarters
entries: Verlas rum ligger på baksidan av stugan. När karaktärerna får tillträde till detta område, läs:
Vad som verkar vara en isstaty av en alv ligger under filtarna på en säng längs rummets östra vägg. Ett litet bord lastat med smutsiga tekoppar och en vattenkokare står bredvid sängen.

Figuren i sängen är den olyckliga Verla Pelc, som smittats av frigid woe av Urgon Wenths aeoriska reliker. Hennes symptom uppstod några veckor efter att butiken rånades, men den tillbakadragna alven berättade aldrig för någon om dem.

entries.name: Development
entries: Om du frågar ut någon av banditerna kan du få fram konkreta ledtrådar som kan föra karaktärerna till Croaker Cave, eller tillbaka till Tulgis stuga om det finns andra frågor som dvärgen ännu inte har besvarat. Om de inte kunde förhöra banditerna kan du låta en av banditerna bära order från Hulil som pekar mot Croaker Cave-gömman.

entries.name: Croaker Cave
entries: Personer som bor i Palebank Village eller som har tillbringat en del tid där känner till Croaker Cave. Om alla karaktärer är nyanlända i byn kan någon av byborna berätta om grottan och hur man tar sig dit.

Croaker Cave har fått sitt namn från de jättelika isgrodor som finns där. Ingången ligger vid stranden av Frigid Depths, norr om Palebank Village. När karaktärerna närmar sig grottans ingång ser de ofta spår av banditer som har kommit och gått. Det finns dock inga tecken på patruller eller vakter. En rökplym stiger upp från marken bortom grottans ingång, och ventileras genom en smal naturlig skorsten från {@adventure area C6|FS|0|C6. Hulil's Cavern}. Skorstenen är dock för liten för att kunna klättras och grottans huvudingång är den enda ingången.

Eftersom hon vet att invånarna i Palebank Village undviker grottan och dess farliga grodor, har {@creature Hulil Lutan|EGW} gjort platsen till sin bas. Hon och de Uttolot-banditer hon kommenderar har domesticerat de gigantiska isgrodor som har grottan som sitt hem och använder dem som vaktdjur.

entries.name: Giant Ice Frogs
entries: Med undantag för {@creature Old Croaker|EGW} (se {@adventure area C5|FS|0|C5. Old Croaker's Pool}) är jättelika isgrodor {@creature Giant Frog||giant frogs} immuna mot köldskador.

De blåskinnade grodorna attackerar alla varelser i grottkomplexet som inte eskorteras av banditer som de känner igen. Var och en slåss tills de har halva sina träffpunkter eller färre och flyr sedan. En karaktär som lyckas med en DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling})-kontroll som en handling övertygar en groda att inte attackera eller att sluta attackera. Om karaktären eller någon av deras allierade attackerar eller skadar grodan återupptar den striden.

Grodorna tillbringar en stor del av sin tid med att vila i pooler med grumligt, iskallt vatten i Croaker Cave. En karaktär som lyckas på en Visdom ({@skill Perception}) kontroll som motsätts av en grodans Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) kontroll lägger märke till en groda som gömmer sig i en pool. Om en groda inte upptäcks attackerar den med överraskning när en karaktär kommer inom 5 fot från poolen.

entries.name: Uttolot Bandits
entries: De banditer som Uttolot-familjen har skickat ut med Hulil är alla dvärgar och alver. Upp till tio banditer brukar normalt ockupera Croaker Cave, men endast tre är närvarande för närvarande (i {@adventure area C2|FS|0|C2. Training Pool}). De använder sig av {@creature bandit} statblocket och har {@sense darkvision} ut till en räckvidd på 60 fot. Dessutom har dvärgarna resistens mot giftskador och har fördel på räddningskast mot gift; alverna har fördel på räddningskast mot att vara {@condition charmed} och immunitet mot magi som skulle få dem att sova.

Uttolot bandits attack any intruders on sight. Each fights until reduced to half its hit points or fewer, then flees the caves. If the characters capture an Uttolot bandit, they can learn the following information with a successful DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check:

items: Hulil is sick with the same malady that killed Urgon Wenth.
She plans on setting out for Shadycreek Run soon, hoping that trading the items her sister Tulgi stole from Pelc's Curiosities allows her to pay for healing that will cure her.

entries.name: Croaker Cave Features
entries: The caverns and tunnels of the Croaker Cave complex are shown on map 5.9. Unless otherwise noted in an area's description, the following features are common throughout all areas of Croaker Cave.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: Cavern ceilings are 10 feet high, with only 8 feet of clearance beneath stalactites.

entries.name: Walls
entries: Climbing the rough walls of a cavern requires a successful DC 12 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: Light
entries: The caverns contain no light sources, except in{@adventure area C6|FS|0|C6. Hulil's Cavern}, as the inhabitants of Croaker Cave rely on {@sense darkvision} to see.

entries.name: Frigid Pools
entries: Pools of murky, frigid water within the caverns are created by melting snow on the rocky ground above dripping down through the ceiling. Each pool is 10 feet deep. A creature completely submerged in a pool must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}. Creatures with resistance or immunity to cold damage automatically succeed on this saving throw. For each minute the creature spends submerged in a pool, it must repeat this saving throw, gaining another level of {@condition exhaustion} on a failure.

entries.name: C1. Entrance Pool
entries: This area of the cave is close enough to the entrance that it is dimly lit by day and on clear moonlit nights. When the characters can see into this area, read:

The slow dripping of water sounds out where it falls from stalactites down into a murky pool that fills the rough tunnel ahead. Every few moments, a loud croaking sounds out from somewhere in the darkness beyond.

With {@sense darkvision} or an appropriate light source, the characters can see a 25-foot-long heavy wooden beam lying against the west wall of the cave at the south end the pool. The Uttolot bandits use the beam to cross the pool, and pull it back to the far side when they are in the cave.
Two giant ice frogs hide in the murky pool. If combat breaks out in this area, the bandits in area C2 quickly come to investigate.

entries.name: C2. Training Pool

entries: The slow dripping of water from the ceiling flows to a pool in the southwest corner of this cavern. A large wooden bucket with a lid sits near the edge of the pool.
Three Uttolot bandits and two giant ice frogs normally occupy this cavern. If the bandits have not yet been alerted to disturbances, they are training the frogs. Add the following:

A dwarf and two elves bundled in layers of winter clothing are throwing dead bats into the air. Two giant blue-skinned frogs leap up to snatch the bats in midair, seemingly as part of some sort of training session.
If the bandits went to investigate disturbances in adjacent areas, the frogs are hiding in the pool.

entries.name: Bucket
entries: The bucket holds six dead bats used as training treats. A character who offers a dead bat to a frog has advantage on their next Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check made to control that frog's behavior.

entries.name: C3. Bat Cavern

entries: This cavern reeks, and its floor is covered in bat guano.

A {@creature swarm of bats} sleeps among the stalactites in this cavern. If anything disturbs the bats (including a light source or a loud noise in the cavern), the swarm attacks the source of the disturbance. The swarm fights until reduced to half its hit points or fewer, then flees out of the cave complex. If combat breaks out in this area, the bandits in area C2 come to investigate.

entries.name: Treacherous Floor
entries: The floor of this area is covered in slippery bat guano. Whenever a creature standing on the floor takes damage, it must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check or fall {@condition prone}.

entries.name: C4. Bandit Camp

entries: Ten empty bedrolls are arranged in a circle around a cold fire pit at the center of this cavern. Chicken bones, empty wine and spirits bottles, and other food waste litters the floor.

One of the bedrolls covers the opening of a 10-foot-deep pit trap. The trap can be spotted with a DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. If not spotted, anyone walking across the bedroll falls into the pit, taking 3 ({@dice 1d6}) bludgeoning damage and landing {@condition prone}. A creature that falls into the pit makes enough noise that the bandits in {@adventure area C2|FS|0|C2. Training Pool} investigate.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Searching all the bedrolls reveals that one contains an unopened bottle of Bald Dwarf Whisky (worth 25 gp), an alcohol made by elves in Uthodurn.

entries.name: C5. Old Croaker's Pool

entries: Water dripping down from stalactites in the ceiling fills a dark pool that completely covers the floor of this cavern.

Croaker Cave's largest denizen—named Old Croaker by the Uttolot bandits—has claimed this pool. It hides in the water and attacks as other giant ice frogs. Old Croaker is a {@creature giant toad} with immunity to cold damage.

{@creature Old Croaker|EGW} has been trained to ferry Hulil and visitors to her cavern (area C6) across the pool. A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check to convince Old Croaker to not attack the party can also convince the frog to ferry all the characters across the pool one at a time.

entries.name: C6. Hulil's Cavern
entries: When the characters can see into this area, read:

A warm rush of heat comes from a massive fire burning in the center of this cavern, its smoke venting up through a narrow stone chimney. The flames illuminate a rough painting of a five-headed dragon that dominates the north wall. A bedroll is spread out beneath the mural. Near the crackling blaze, a dwarf bundled in a heavy cloak sits on a stone chest beside an elf whose face is covered in dragon tattoos. The dwarf's face is streaked with pulsing blue veins.

{@creature Hulil Lutan|EGW} (a neutral evil, female mountain dwarf {@creature cult fanatic} with a walking speed of 15 feet, {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet, resistance to poison damage, and advantage on saving throws against poison) and her apprentice, {@creature Raegrin Mau|EGW} (a neutral evil, male wood elf {@creature cultist} with {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet, advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and immunity to magic that would put him to sleep), are both in a state of deep meditation, praying to Tiamat for a cure for the dwarf's affliction. Even if combat broke out in area C5, they remain unaware of the characters' presence until they are disturbed or attacked. Hulil and Raegrin are both greedy servants of Tiamat and the Uttolot family. Raegrin follows Hulil's every order with unshaking loyalty.

Hulil is so desperate for a cure for the ailment that is slowly killing her that she doesn't attack the characters when she first sees them, as long as she isn't attacked first. Instead, she orders them to stand down and demands to know why they came to the cave. A quick-thinking character can claim to have come to help Hulil (at the direction of her sister, after receiving a message from Tiamat, or with another appropriate rationale). With a successful Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check opposed by Hulil's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, the character convinces the dwarf that all the characters are her allies. On a failed check, or if the characters challenge her, Hulil and Raegrin attack.

entries.name: Campfire
entries: Any creature that enters the area of the fire for the first time on its turn, or that starts its turn there, takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) fire damage.

entries.name: What Hulil Knows
entries: If the characters convince {@creature Hulil Lutan|EGW|Hulil} that they are her allies, or if they capture her or Raegrin and succeed on a DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check, they can learn the following information:

items: Hulil believes she has a disease called frigid woe. Though she doesn't know any more about the disease than its symptoms, she's heard rumors that explorers in Eiselcross sometimes succumb to it.

Hulil has guessed that her affliction was caused by one of the blue vials Tulgi stole from Pelc's Curiosities, originally sold by Urgon Wenth. The vial was cracked, revealing that its lovely color was the result of a dark blue dust clinging to the interior.
She is desperate to get to Shadycreek Run before the malady runs its course, hoping that she can trade the goods stolen by Tulgi for a cure.

entries: Hulil used one of the vials to trap the chest containing the other stolen items (see "Stone Chest" below). Needing quick cash for the trip, she sold the other vial to Irven Liel, a human merchant staying at the Jolly Dwarf inn in Palebank Village while traveling with his family to Uthodurn.

entries.name: Stone Chest
entries: The stone chest's outer lid is carved with the face of a dragon. A character who examines the chest and succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check finds pin-sized openings in the dragon's mouth that contain a blue powder. The powder can be removed with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. A character who fails this check must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or contract frigid woe (see the "{@book Eiselcross|EGW|4}" section of chapter 3).

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals that the chest radiates an aura of evocation magic. When a creature touches the chest without speaking a prayer to Tiamat, a gust of wind escapes the dragon's mouth. If the blue powder is still in the dragon's mouth, it forms a cloud that fills a 15-foot cube in front of the chest. Each creature within the area must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or contract frigid woe.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest contains the rest of the treasure found by Urgon Wenth—a gilded scroll case covered in a cosmological map of the multiverse (worth 15 gp), a jade statuette of a storm giant (25 gp), a quiver containing six {@item +1 Arrow||+1 arrows}, and a silver ring set with a jasper stone (50 gp). It also holds Hulil's wealth—415 cp, 234 sp, 43 ep, and 112 gp—and a receipt indicating that Hulil sold a blue glass vial to Irven Liel for 100 gp.

entries.name: Development
entries: When the characters are done exploring Croaker Cave, they should know the blue glass vials found by Urgon Wenth are the source of the strange malady that is turning people into ice statues, and that Irven Liel has one of those vials. If the characters don't have a chance to question {@creature Hulil Lutan|EGW|Hulil} or {@creature Raegrin Mau|EGW|Raegrin}, you can have the chest also contain a journal or notes that provide the information they need and point them toward the Jolly Dwarf inn.

entries.name: Jolly Dwarf
entries: The Jolly Dwarf is a cozy, two-story inn run by a retired adventurer named Arl Bortock. When the characters enter the inn, read:

The downstairs of this inn features a large taproom. A gray-haired dwarf behind the bar greets you cheerfully as you enter. Two male humans and two tiefling children laugh among themselves as they enjoy a meal together.
Arl Bortock (a neutral good, male, mountain dwarf {@creature veteran}) works behind the bar. If the characters ask for Irven Liel, the dwarf points them toward the laughing family.

Irven Liel, his husband Fenton Tethwick (both neutral good, male Dwendalian human {@creature Commoner||commoners}), and their adopted daughters Honor and Magic (both tiefling noncombatants) are friendly and invite the characters to join them. Irven and Fenton are traveling booksellers. If asked about the vial, Irven explains that they met {@creature Hulil Lutan|EGW} on the road to Palebank Village. She said she was moving and needed to shed some possessions, so she offered him a chance to buy the Aeorian relic at a great price. He plans to sell the item for a profit in Uthodurn.

If the characters tell Irven the truth about the vial, he panics, saying that everyone in his family has touched the object. Fenton gives the vial to the characters, handing it to them wrapped up in a cloth. Any character who touches the vial directly must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or contract frigid woe.

entries.name: Development
entries: Once the characters have the cracked vial, they can report back to Elro Aldataur. He pays them 100 gp as promised but asks the characters to stay in town. He is quite certain he'll have need of their services again soon.

The next morning, Elro comes to the characters with somber news. Irven, Fenton, Honor, and Magic are all afflicted with frigid woe. Seeing the blue powder in the vial has allowed Elro to consult old lore and learn a few things about the disease. (If the characters didn't learn the name of the affliction from Hulil, Elro is the source of that name as well.)

Elro knows that frigid woe is said to have only one cure—a milky liquid the Aeorians stored in gold vials. He hopes that the cure might be found in the same place Urgon found the vials of frigid woe in Eiselcross. The retired ranger asks the characters to travel to the islands of Eiselcross and retrace Urgon's path, hoping they can find the cure. He offers the party 200 gp for the task, and reminds them that time is of the essence for Irven and his family—not to mention for any characters infected with frigid woe. If the characters accept, Elro gives them a day to prepare and tells them to find him at the village docks when they're ready to set sail.

entries.name: Vials of Frigid Woe
entries: As an action, a creature can throw a vial of frigid woe up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact and releasing its contents as a cloud of spores. Each creature within 5 feet of the vial when it shatters must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or contract frigid woe (see the "{@book Eiselcross|EGW|4}" section of chapter 3).

If a character has contracted frigid woe, track the number of days that have passed so you can inform the player when their character's symptoms appear and when they need to make Constitution saving throws.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: The characters advance to 2nd level before traveling to Eiselcross.

entries.name: Traveling to Eiselcross
entries: When the characters are ready to leave for Eiselcross, Elro Aldataur provides them with the following information:

items: Elro has arranged passage to Eiselcross for the characters on the {@i Remorhaz}, a sailing ship owned and operated by the Glassblades.

The characters will be taken to Syrinlya, an Uthodurnian outpost on Foren, Eiselcross's largest island. Once there, they should talk to a dwarf named Orvo Mustave, who has gone on numerous expeditions into the wilds of Eiselcross with Urgon Wenth.

Once the characters have found the cure, they should use whatever they need for themselves, then give the rest to an elf in Syrinlya who goes by the name "the Buyer." They can tell the Buyer to teleport the cure to Elro in Palebank Village.

entries: The islands of Eiselcross are covered in ice and snow, and are always well below freezing. Characters who don't already have cold weather gear will want to purchase it, or they will be subject to {@hazard extreme cold} (see {@book chapter 5|DMG|5|Weather} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

entries.name: NPCs Infected with Frozen Woe
entries: The characters are in a race against time to cure Irven and his family (and possibly Hulil and Tulgi Lutan, if the characters are feeling merciful toward those two hardened criminals). Irven and his family have at least sixty days before any of them might die, Hulil has at least thirty days, and Tulgi has at least twenty days. You can make saving throws for these NPCs against the disease every ten days, or you can just decide their final fates.

entries.name: Voyage of the Remorhaz
entries: It takes the {@i Remorhaz} nine days to get to Syrinlya. This trip could be uneventful, or you could populate the ship with interesting NPCs and have the characters encounter ocean monsters, Revelry pirates, or severe weather.
When the ship reaches Syrinlya, read:

The temperature has steadily dropped since you left Palebank Village, yet it seems to grow colder still as you step off the ramp of the {@i Remorhaz} onto Foren. Through windy snow, you can see fur-lined tents and yurts arranged in a large camp. Campfires are whipped by the wind, with dwarves and elves huddled close to the flames.

"Don't worry! It'll cool down here eventually!" a joking voice bellows over the snow. A female dwarf with a shaggy mane of unkempt hair bows to you. "Morgo Delwur at your service. Welcome to Eiselcross!"

Morgo Delwur (a neutral good, female mountain dwarf {@creature werebear}) has lived in Syrinlya for years. She can show the characters around and answer any questions they have about the settlement, providing any of the details found in {@book chapter 3|EGW|4|Syrinlya}. If the characters ask about Orvo Mustave or the Buyer, Morgo points out where both live. Though Morgo never adventured with Urgon Wenth and wasn't a close friend, she is sad to hear of the dwarf's passing.

Morgo and the other explorers in Syrinlya know about frigid woe and the disease's terrible effects. If the characters have any unanswered questions about the disease, the explorers share what they know.

entries.name: Syrinlya
entries: As Morgo leads the characters through Syrinlya, read:

Morgo gestures to the groups of dwarves and elves huddled and chatting around campfires. "They're planning expeditions to find Aeor's lost treasures," she says. "That's what this whole place is about. If you ain't exploring, you ain't banking gold."

The dwarf stops in front of a large fur-lined yurt. "You can stay here. Belonged to a fool rich elf named Bertron who came here looking for adventure. He found the inside of a saber-toothed tiger instead. Should be some food and the like in there. It's yours now."

entries.name: Bertron's Yurt
entries: The characters are welcome to this yurt during their time in Syrinlya. When they first enter, read:

The sound of wind and the biting cold die down as you enter the yurt. A cold fire pit marks the center of the hide-covered floor. An open crate containing packaged rations and a few other items stands next to the door.

Once the characters are settled, Morgo wishes them luck and leaves to prepare for an expedition of her own (see the "Can You Help Us?" sidebar). The crate contains 50 days of rations, a 50-foot silk rope, a blanket, a grappling hook, a miner's pick, and a book titled {@i Adventure Sexy: Impress Potential Lovers with Great Deeds} by Scanlan Shorthalt.

entries.name: Can You Help Us?
entries: If the characters feel as though they need help traveling the wilds of Foren, they can try to convince other explorers in Syrinlya to travel with them to recover the cure. Although most of Syrinlya's explorers are willing to help others in need, those explorers already have an important mission. An expedition led by Professor Gulrim Shalebrow (see "{@book The Diarchy of Uthodurn|EGW|3|Diarchy of Uthodurn}" in chapter 2) went to search for the origin of the strange magic in the region of Mutalos months ago and has not returned. The explorers at the camp are preparing a search and rescue mission to bring back Gulrim's party. If the characters survive their quest into Salsvault, this story could serve as a hook for another adventure.

entries.name: The Buyer
entries: Morgo Delwur or any other resident of Syrinlya can point out the Buyer's hut to the characters. It is Syrinlya's largest yurt. When the characters enter, read:

The pungent scent of incense fills this yurt, whose walls are painted with glowing arcane runes. A brass brazier burns brightly at the center of the floor, around which are set a few plush chairs, a bed, and a large stone chest. On one of those chairs sits an elf reading a book. A small dragon with green butterfly wings is curled in the elf's lap.

The Buyer (lawful neutral, nonbinary, high elf {@creature mage}) is a mysterious elf who purchases Aeorian relics in Syrinlya for the Uthodurnian government. See the "{@book Syrinlya|EGW|4|Syrinlya}" section of chapter 3 for more information about the Buyer and their business. The green {@creature Faerie Dragon (Violet)||faerie dragon} is Dew, the elf's familiar.

The Buyer has been in Syrinlya since the day the outpost was founded. They can answer any questions the characters might have about the outpost's history, the island of Foren, or frigid woe. If the characters want to confirm that the Buyer is able to quickly send the cure for frigid woe to Palebank Village, the elf tells them that the stone chest in the yurt has the magical capability to teleport objects on command.
In addition to the aid they provide in getting the cure back to Palebank Village, the Buyer offers to purchase any Aeorian relics the characters want to sell.

entries.name: Stone Chest
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals that the chest radiates an aura of conjuration magic. When an item is placed in the chest, the Buyer can teleport it to secret locations in Uthodurn or its outpost of Palebank Village, with those locations known only to the authorities of those settlements.

entries.name: Orvo Mustave
entries: Morgo Delwur or any other resident of Syrinlya can point out Orvo Mustave's tent to the characters. When the characters approach the tent, read:

A campfire burns in front of this small tent, whose flaps are open. Inside the tent sits a young dwarf whose face is scarred as though scratched by a large claw. A shortsword is casually laid across his lap as he warms his outstretched hands.

Orvo Mustave (a chaotic good, male mountain dwarf {@creature scout}) is a curious and soft-spoken explorer. He enjoys uncovering the secrets of Eiselcross as much as he does uncovering the region's treasures. He is genuinely interested in the characters' lives, and asks them lots of questions after inviting them to share his fire.

entries.name: Orvo's Story
entries: Orvo is grief-stricken to hear about the demise of his friend Urgon Wenth. If the characters ask Orvo about the blue vials that brought disease to Palebank Village, Orvo shares the following information:

items: Orvo and Urgon found the blue vials in Salsvault, an Aeorian ruin partially submerged in water in a region of Foren where the glacial ice is thin. Explorers call this region Thin Sheets. Orvo believes the ruin is as well preserved as it is because the structure was reinforced with magic, as were many of Aeor's buildings that housed hazardous materials or secret projects.
Salsvault is two hundred miles northwest of Syrinlya. Ice mephits are drawn to the magic of something at that location. Orvo and Urgon found the ruin after following one of the creatures.
Salsvault appears to have been an Aeorian lab. Orvo and Urgon explored only three of its chambers before being chased away by animated suits of armor.
The dwarves didn't know what the vials contained.
Orvo sold his share of the treasure from Salsvault to the Buyer. Urgon decided to hang onto his share until he returned home to Palebank Village.

entries.name: Into the Wilds
entries: After speaking with Orvo, the characters can make whatever preparations they need before heading into the wilds of Eiselcross. If they wish to obtain more supplies before setting out, there are no shops in Syrinlya, but many of the explorers at the camp are willing to trade goods and equipment.

entries.name: Overland Travel
entries: The characters must travel two hundred miles over ice and snow to reach Salsvault, the ruin where Urgon Wenth found the vials of frigid woe. It's up to the characters whether they want to move at a fast, medium, or slow pace (see "{@book Movement|PHB|8|Movement}" in chapter 8 of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}). If any character has a walking speed of less than 25 feet because of a frigid woe infection, use the Reduced Travel Speeds table to determine how far the party can travel in a day.

entries.name: Reduced Travel Speeds
entries: As the characters travel, use the "{@book Encounters in Eiselcross|EGW|4|Encounters in Eiselcross}" section in chapter 3 to generate random encounters. After traveling forty miles, the characters enter Thin Sheets. This region is known for its large patches of thin ice over deep, {@hazard frigid water} (see the rules for frigid water and thin ice in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5|Wilderness Hazards} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

entries.name: Finding Salsvault
entries: When the characters have traveled two hundred miles, one character who acts as a scout for the group should make a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Survival}) check each day. On a failure, the character finds no signs of Salsvault. On a success, the character finds the trail of an ice mephit, which leads to Salsvault after a journey of {@dice 1d4} hours. If the check succeeds by 5 or more, the character finds Salsvault directly.

entries.name: Salsvault
entries: Salsvault was once a laboratory in the city of Aeor, where mages who specialized in necromancy and transmutation magic crafted constructs and diseases to be weaponized against their enemies. Many of the laboratory's creations remain active, still guarding the diseases and treasures within.

entries.name: Approaching Salsvault
entries: As the characters approach Salsvault, read:

Through wind-whipped snow and biting cold, you notice a half-submerged, dark-blue stone building poking up through the ice. A gray stone door is carved to look like a face with a half-exposed skull. Scribed above the door is the word "SALSVAULT."

Ziro and Glacies, two {@creature Ice Mephit||ice mephits}, hide near the entrance to Salsvault, waiting for someone to open the door. A character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 13 or higher notices the mephits. If any characters interact with the mephits, they attack in response. If the characters don't notice the mephits, the creatures follow them inside Salsvault, attracted to the frigid woe within. The first time the characters enter an area containing vials of frigid woe, the mephits seek out and break the vials, reveling in releasing the cold-based magical energy within.

entries.name: Sealed Entrance
entries: The entrance to Salsvault is frozen shut. The characters can force the door open with a successful DC 15 Strength check or by dealing 10 bludgeoning or fire damage to the ice that seals the door. Unsealing the door with bludgeoning damage draws the attention of three suits of animated armor in area{@adventure S3|FS|0|S3. Animated Armor Laboratory}, which gather in {@adventure area S1|FS|0|S1. Entrance Chamber} and attack the characters as soon as they enter.

entries.name: Salsvault Features
entries: The locations in Salsvault are detailed on map 5.10. Unless otherwise noted in an area's description, the following features are common throughout all areas of Salsvault.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: The ceilings in Salsvault's rooms are 10 feet high, with 8-foot-high doorways connecting them.

entries.name: Chests
entries: Stone chests two feet on each side are built into the floors in several areas. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a faint aura of abjuration magic radiating from each chest. A chest has AC 17; 27 hit points; resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage; and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

If an area's description notes a locked chest, the chest's lock can be picked with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools or forced open with a successful DC 18 Strength check. {@creature Ferol Sal|EGW} (see {@adventure area S17|FS|0|S17. Ferol's Laboratory}) carries a master key that locks or unlocks all chests in Salsvault.

entries.name: Doors and Walls
entries: Salsvault's heavy doors are made of black stone, and its walls are made of blue stone. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a faint aura of abjuration magic radiating from the doors and walls. Each door and each 10-foot section of wall has AC 17; 27 hit points; resistance to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage; and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

If an area's description notes a locked door, the lock can be picked with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools, or the door can be forced open with a successful DC 18 Strength check. {@creature Ferol Sal|EGW} (see {@adventure area S17|FS|0|S17. Ferol's Laboratory}) carries a master key that locks or unlocks all the doors in Salsvault.

entries.name: Aeorian Robes
entries: The undead in the complex wear archaic-looking robes. With a successful DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill History}) check, a character recognizes the robes as being of Aeorian style. The characters can also find intact robes of the same style in the complex. Constructs and zombies in the complex don't attack a character wearing intact robes, unless the character attacks first.

entries.name: Eastern Slope
entries: Salsvault is tilted in the ice, with its east side lower than its west side. Every area within the complex features a gentle slope downward to the east.

entries.name: Light
entries: Unless otherwise noted, wall sconces with {@spell continual flame} spells cast on them brightly light the interior of Salsvault.

entries.name: Temperature
entries: Though Salsvault's interior is guarded from wind and snow, the temperatures within the structure are still well below freezing.

entries.name: Water
entries: Some areas of Salsvault are partially filled with seawater flowing in from beneath the ice of Thin Sheets. A creature that starts its turn in the frigid water must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}. Creatures that lair within the water in the complex are immune to this effect.

entries.name: Denizens of Salsvault
entries: Many of the creatures the characters can encounter in Salsvault have similar characteristics and tactics.

entries.name: Beasts
entries: Several sea creatures haunt the submerged areas of the complex. These beasts attack characters who enter the water, fighting until reduced to half their hit points or fewer before fleeing.

entries.name: Constructs
entries: When Salsvault crashed into Foren, a number of its construct guardians survived. Those constructs continue to guard the complex, fighting intruders until they flee Salsvault. The constructs won't leave the complex willingly and won't pursue characters who do so. The constructs don't attack the undead of Salsvault, understanding on some level that those undead are the remains of the people who created them.

entries.name: Undead
entries: The humanoids working in Salsvault died when it crashed into Foren. Just before impact, {@creature Ferol Sal|EGW}, the necromancer in charge of Salsvault, released an experimental disease that caused any humanoids who died in the complex to return as undead. Most of those affected returned as zombies that attack intruders on sight and fight to the death. Ferol returned as a wight and has continued to work obsessively in his personal lab ({@adventure area S17|FS|0|S17. Ferol's Laboratory}) ever since. Because of the cold here, all the undead are relatively well preserved.

entries.name: S1. Entrance Chamber

entries: The heavy stone walls of this room dampen the cold and the howling wind outside. An inscription in what looks like Draconic runes is carved into the east wall.

The inscription is in an archaic version of Draconic that was spoken in ancient Aeor. It can be read by any character who can read Draconic with a few minutes of study, or by anyone with access to a {@spell comprehend languages} spell or similar magic. The message reads: "Welcome to Salsvault! Visitors, please wait here for an escort, and DO NOT TOUCH ANYTHING WITHOUT PERMISSION."
If the characters make any noise louder than a whisper in this chamber, the suits of animated armor in {@adventure area S3|FS|0|S3. Animated Armor Laboratory} come to investigate.

entries.name: Locked Door
entries: The door that leads to {@adventure area S4|FS|0|S4. Frigid Woe Laboratory} is locked (see "{@adventure Salsvault Features|FS|0|Salsvault Features}," at the beginning of this section).

entries.name: Open Door
entries: The door that leads to area S2 is slightly ajar. A character who examines the door and succeeds on a DC 10 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check notes that it was recently forced open (by Urgon and Orvo when they explored Salsvault).

entries.name: S2. Ransacked Frigid Woe Laboratory

entries: Stone tables lie in pieces on the floor at the east end of the room. Two open stone chests stand against the west wall. A layer of fine sand coats the inside of the chests and the floor around them.
If the characters make any noise louder than a whisper in this chamber, the suits of animated armor in area S3 investigate the noise.

Any examination of the chests reveals that they are built into the floor. A character who examines the sand on the ground near the chest and succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices two sets of dwarf-sized boot prints (from Orvo and Urgon) as well as two sets of boot prints made by human-sized feet (the animated armor from area S3).

entries.name: S3. Animated Armor Laboratory

entries: Pieces of rusty plate armor are scattered about this chamber amid the rubble of destroyed stone furniture. An anvil built into the floor stands in front of a cold furnace to the southwest. Across the room from the furnace, two humanoid feet stick out from a pile of rubble.

Two suits of {@creature animated armor} normally stand guard in this chamber. If the armor didn't leave to investigate disturbances in {@adventure areas S1|FS|0|S1. Entrance Chamber} or S2, both suits are here when the characters arrive, and you can add the following:
Two full suits of steel armor stand upright but empty in the middle of the chamber, their gleaming surfaces a stark contrast to the rusty pieces lying nearby.

entries.name: Rescue Mission
entries: One of the blacksmiths who worked in this chamber was crushed by a stone table that broke into rubble when Salsvault crashed into Foren. Since then, the blacksmith has been a {@creature zombie} {@condition restrained} beneath the rubble and unable to break free. Any character who examines the feet notices them twitching with a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.

If the characters want to help the "victim" under the rubble, one character can remove enough rubble to free the zombie in 10 minutes. Multiple characters working together can reduce the time proportionately. As soon as it is freed, the zombie attacks.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The zombie wears an apron containing a set of damaged mithral smith's tools (worth 50 gp).

entries.name: S4. Frigid Woe Laboratory

entries: Smashed stone tables litter the floor in this chamber. Two stone chests built into the floor stand next to each other along the far wall. A door to the west is inscribed with words in Draconic runes. A large iron lever is flipped into the up position on the wall next to the door.
The inscription in archaic Draconic reads: "Disease storage. Authorized personnel only."

entries.name: Chests
entries: These stone chests are locked (see "{@adventure Salsvault Features|FS|0|Salsvault Features}" at the beginning of this section) and magically trapped. When a creature makes a failed attempt to pick the chest's lock, or attacks or attempts to force the chest open, the chest shoots a beam of cold energy at the creature. The beam is +4 to hit and deals 4 ({@dice 1d8}) cold damage on a hit.

A character who searches the exterior of either chest and succeeds on a DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check finds an archaic Draconic word for "ice" carved in tiny letters near the hinges. With a successful DC 10 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check, a character senses that the inscription is connected to a trap. Scratching out the inscription with a tool or a weapon causes the trap to stop functioning on that chest.
Each chest is packed with fine sand, within which are nestled two vials of frigid woe (see the "{@adventure Vials of Frigid Woe|FS|0|Vials of Frigid Woe}" sidebar earlier in this adventure).

entries.name: Iron Lever
entries: A character who examines the lever notices spots of faded red paint on it with a successful DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. As an action, a creature can pull the lever down, causing flames to shoot down from the ceiling in {@adventure area S5|FS|0|S5. Disease Storage}. Even with the door closed, a hiss can be heard in this area when the flames are active. A creature can use an action to push the lever back up, which shuts off the flames. See area S5 for more information on this hazard.

entries.name: Locked Doors
entries: The doors from this area to {@adventure areas S1|FS|0|S1. Entrance Chamber} and S5 are locked. The door to area S5 is also trapped.

entries.name: Trapped Door
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of conjuration magic radiating from the locked door to area S5. When a creature makes a failed attempt to pick the door's lock, or attacks or attempts to force the door open, that creature is teleported into the middle of {@adventure area S15|FS|0|S15. Animated Weapon Storage}.

A character who searches the door and succeeds on a DC 13 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check finds an archaic Draconic word for "disappear" carved in tiny letters near the foot of the door on both sides. With a successful DC 10 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check, a character senses that the inscription is connected to a trap. Scratching out either inscription with a tool or a weapon causes the trap to stop functioning.

entries.name: S5. Disease Storage
entries: If the iron lever in area S4 has been raised, read the following when the door to this room is opened:
A wave of heat hits you from the wall of roiling flame that fills this area, shooting down from the ceiling.
If the flames are off, read:
The only things to be seen in this room are eight chests built into the floor along the far wall.

If the flames are active, each creature that enters this area or starts its turn there must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 4 ({@dice 1d8}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.
If the flames aren't active, a character who succeeds on a DC 13 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notes a faint oily smell in the room and notices pin-sized holes covering the ceiling.

entries.name: Chests
entries: Each chest is locked (see "{@adventure Salsvault Features|FS|0|Salsvault Features}" at the beginning of this section), packed with fine sand, and contains three vials of frigid woe (see the "{@adventure Vials of Frigid Woe|FS|0|Vials of Frigid Woe}" sidebar earlier in this adventure).

entries.name: S6. North Hall
entries: Three human {@creature Zombie||zombies} in tattered Aeorian robes roam this hall aimlessly and attack intruders on sight.

entries.name: S7. Unoccupied Dorm

entries: Four unmade beds are built into the east and west walls here, each with a footlocker tucked beneath it.
One of the footlockers holds an intact Aeorian robe (see "{@adventure Salsvault Features|FS|0|Salsvault Features}" at the beginning of this section).

entries.name: S8. Ruined Dorm
entries: Salsvault's crash into Foren destroyed the magic torches in this room, leaving it shrouded in darkness. When the characters can see into this area, read:
Debris from broken stone furniture covers the floor. The walls here are cracked, as if they once supported built-in shelves that have been reduced to rubble.

The floor of this chamber is covered in rubble, making it {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. A {@creature rug of smothering} is hidden beneath the rubble. A character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher notices the rug, but gets no hint that it is animated.

A search of the rubble and a successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check turns up an intact Aeorian robe (see "{@adventure Salsvault Features|FS|0|Salsvault Features}" at the beginning of this section).

entries.name: S9. Zombie Dorm
entries: When the characters can see into this area, read:

Footlockers are tucked beneath four beds attached to the north and south walls. In the middle of the room, four zombies in tattered robes shuffle around, softly knocking into one another without caring.
The four {@creature Zombie||zombies} attack as soon as they see intruders. The footlockers are empty.

entries.name: S10. Ferol Sal's Chamber
entries: The door to Ferol Sal's personal quarters is locked. When the characters can see this area, read:

This room is in immaculate condition, apparently having been cleaned up after the destruction seen elsewhere in the complex. A crisply made bed stands at the center of the west wall, with small tables off to either side. The room also contains a stone desk set with a chair, and a chest built into the floor.
Though the undead Ferol no longer sleeps here, he and the zombies tidied up his personal space after Salsvault crashed into Eiselcross.

entries.name: Chest
entries: The chest contains Ferol's treasure (see below), along with a {@creature swarm of undead snakes|EGW} that attacks any creature that opens the chest. The swarm uses the stat block for a {@creature swarm of poisonous snakes}, with these changes:

items: The swarm is made of Tiny undead that don't require air, food, drink, or sleep.
The swarm has immunity to poison damage and the {@condition poisoned} condition.

entries.name: Desk
entries: Any search of the desk turns up a bottle of dried ink, several used quills, five sheets of blank parchment, and a piece of paper with a faded message written on it in archaic Draconic. A character who understands Draconic can spend a few minutes to piece together the meaning of the note, or it can be deciphered with a {@spell comprehend languages} spell or similar magic. The note reads:
To whomever finds this:

All my people are dead: my family, my friends, and my workers. I, too, am dead. Were it not for my quick thinking and prowess with necromancy, our important work at Salsvault would be over. I continue to labor in my undead form, trying to find a sickness that can infect the gods themselves. If I have perished, I implore you to find my lab, find my notes, and finish my work. The gods must pay for Aeor's destruction.
—Ferol Sal

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest contains 1,006 sp, 45 ep, and 201 gp in Aeorian coinage.

entries.name: S11. Kitchen
entries: Salsvault's crash into Foren destroyed the magic torches in this room, leaving it shrouded in darkness. When the characters can see into this area, read:
Iron pots, pans, utensils, and frost-covered food covers the floor of this kitchen. A steel stove is built into the west wall.

When the characters enter the room, four {@creature Animated Knife|EGW|animated kitchen knives} fly up from the floor and attack. The knives are {@creature Flying Sword||flying swords}, with these changes:

items: Each knife is a Tiny construct with 12 ({@dice 5d4}) hit points and a challenge rating of 1/8 (25 XP).
Instead of a longsword attack, each knife makes a melee attack (+4 to hit) that deals 3 ({@dice 1d4 + 1}) piercing damage on a hit.

entries: Old frozen cheese, bread, meat, and produce cover the floor, all well rimed and inedible.

entries.name: S12. Dining Hall

entries: The remains of broken tables and chairs are piled along the east wall. Two human zombies in tattered robes shuffle aimlessly around each other at the center of the chamber.
The two {@creature Zombie||zombies} occupying the dining hall attack any intruders. All the other features of this room have been reduced to rubble.

entries.name: S13. Drowned Library

entries: Water ebbs and flows through a large opening along the east wall of this ruined library. Rotting parchments and waterlogged tomes are spread everywhere, fallen from cracked stone shelves.

The water is deeper than it appears beneath the ruined books and parchments, with the floor along the eastern side of the room having collapsed to a depth of 15 feet. A {@creature giant octopus} hides here, having claimed this room as its lair. A character who succeeds on a Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check opposed by the octopus's Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check notices the beast. See "{@adventure Salsvault Features|FS|0|Salsvault Features}," earlier in this section, for the effects of entering the water.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 12 or higher, or one who succeeds on a DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, notices a watertight scroll case floating in the water. The case holds two {@item Spell Scroll||spell scrolls} of {@spell detect magic}.

entries.name: S14. South Hall
entries: Three well-preserved human {@creature Zombie||zombies} in tattered robes roam this hall aimlessly, attacking any intruders that catch their attention.

entries.name: S15. Animated Weapon Storage
entries: The door to this room is locked. When the characters can see into this area, read:
Broken blades, cracked hammers, frost-rotted spears, and other ruined weapons are spread out across the floor, fallen from the empty iron weapon racks that line the walls.

The mages of Salsvault stored animated weapons in this room, most of which were destroyed in the crash. Five {@creature Flying Sword||flying swords} lay among the debris, attacking any characters who enter.
The broken weapons on the floor make this area {@quickref difficult terrain||3}. Any creature that falls {@condition prone} in this room takes 2 ({@dice 1d4}) piercing damage.

entries.name: S16. Golem Laboratory
entries: As the characters approach this room, read:
A large red X is painted across the stone door before you. Violent banging and the sound of heavy objects being tossed around emanates from the chamber beyond.
The door is locked. If the characters open it, read:

As you open the door to this debris-filled room, a humanoid creature made of pieces of stitched-together flesh charges toward you. The monster's body is covered in wounds, and broken pieces of bone stick through its skin at odd angles.

When Salsvault crashed into Foren, this golem servant of the mages was driven mad from the damage it took. Ferol locked the golem in this room ages ago. The {@creature Damaged Flesh Golem|EGW|golem} uses the {@creature flesh golem} stat block, with these changes:

items: The golem has 5 hit points remaining, and its Berserk trait is activated.
The golem has the use of only one arm and can't use its Multiattack. Its challenge rating is 1 (200 XP).

entries.name: Debris
entries: The golem has long since smashed all the objects in this chamber not destroyed by Salsvault's crash. Any search of the debris turns up only bits of bone, clay, iron, stone, and paper.

entries.name: S17. Ferol's Laboratory

entries: Six long stone tables are set with steel and glass laboratory equipment in this chamber, whose walls are lined with shelves holding all manner of strange knickknacks and tools. An armed humanoid with white skin and red eyes moves from table to table, adjusting bubbling mixtures and carefully adding reagents.

The undead {@creature Ferol Sal|EGW} has worked tirelessly in the laboratory for centuries, obsessed with crafting a disease that can kill the gods. Despite having made no progress in all that time, he keeps working. Ferol is a {@creature wight} with an Intelligence of 16 (+3).

entries.name: Roleplaying Ferol
entries: Ferol knows nothing of Exandria's history since Aeor's crash, and his memory of the distant past is almost as hazy. His transformation into a wight and the centuries of solitude since have driven him quite mad. He cares only about taking revenge on the gods—who he incorrectly assumes are still active in Exandria. As a resident of Aeor, Ferol doesn't speak Common, though he can communicate in the archaic Draconic of Aeor, as well as an archaic form of Elven. Characters who speak Draconic or Elven can communicate with him, albeit slowly.

When Ferol notices the characters, he demands to know what they're doing in Salsvault. Any character who claims they have come to help Ferol with his work and succeeds on a Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check opposed by the wight's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check earns the undead's trust. The check is made with advantage if characters who found and were able to read the note in {@adventure area S10|FS|0|S10. Ferol Sal's Chamber} mention Ferol's plans to craft a god-killing disease.

If Ferol trusts the characters, he tells them to stay away from the locked golem lab ({@adventure area S16|FS|0|S16. Golem Laboratory}). If they ask about the cure for frigid woe, he tells them they can find it locked in a chest in what he calls the curative laboratory (area S18). A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check can convince Ferol to provide the key that safely unlocks the chest.
If the characters don't earn Ferol's trust, the wight attacks, fighting until destroyed.

entries.name: Ferol's Keys
entries: Ferol carries two keys: one that works all the doors in Salsvault and another that works all the chests built into the floor within the complex (see "{@adventure Salsvault Features|FS|0|Salsvault Features}").

entries.name: Shelves
entries: The shelves hold spell components, reagents, and laboratory supplies that are far past their prime. However, a character who spends a few minutes searching the shelves can collect enough workable tools and reagents to put together a set of alchemist's supplies.

entries.name: Tables
entries: Each table holds a working set of alchemist's supplies that Ferol uses to experiment with frigid woe. If a creature is forcibly moved into a table, the delicate equipment on that table breaks and the creature must succeed on a DC 11 Constitution saving throw or contract frigid woe.

entries.name: S18. Drowned Curative Laboratory

entries: A cold wind howls through the collapsed east wall of this huge chamber, whose far side is completely submerged under frigid seawater. A dense bed of kelp grows up from the submerged floor, obscuring any sight of what lies below. Broken glass and the remains of shattered tables cover the floor in the dry section of the room.

Aeorian mages worked in this chamber to ensure that they could cure the diseases they created. Four {@creature Giant Crab||giant crabs} now lair here, hiding beneath the kelp in the 5-foot-deep water and attacking any creatures that intrude. A character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 14 or higher notices the crabs, which attack with surprise if not spotted. See "{@adventure Salsvault Features|FS|0|Salsvault Features}," at the beginning of this section, for what happens if characters enter the frigid water. Additionally, the kelp makes the water {@quickref difficult terrain||3} for creatures other than the giant crabs.

entries.name: Chest
entries: A character with a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 11 or higher notices a stone chest built into the floor and submerged in the water against the back wall. The chest is locked (see "Salsvault Features" at the beginning of this section).

entries.name: Kelp
entries: The kelp counts as {@quickref difficult terrain||3}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest is packed with fine sand and contains twenty doses of frigid woe antidote (see "{@book Eiselcross|EGW|4|Eiselcross}" in chapter 3) and an {@item ersatz eye|XGE} (see {@book chapter 6|EGW|7|Ersatz Eye}).

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: You can roll for random encounters on the way back to Syrinlya (see "{@book Encounters in Eiselcross|EGW|4|Encounters in Eiselcross}" in chapter 3), or you can allow the characters an uneventful trip as reward for a job well done. When the characters arrive in Syrinlya, they can arrange for the Buyer to teleport the antidote for frigid woe to Palebank Village. After doing so, the elf pays out the 200 gp reward on behalf of Elro Aldataur.

If the characters don't successfully recover the frigid woe antidote in time to save Irven and his family, all four family members succumb to the disease. If the characters are successful, they have the thanks of Elro Aldataur, Irven and his family, the people of Palebank Village, and the explorers of Syrinlya.

entries.name: Character Advancement
entries: At the end of this adventure, the characters reach 3rd level. This might mark the beginning of a campaign in the Biting North. In particular, the Buyer suggests that the characters could easily find their fortunes exploring Eiselcross. Alternatively, their success in this mission might inspire the characters to seek out new realms and new adventures elsewhere in Wildemount.
